newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: Czech cen. bank battles crown speculators again.
newsitem.headline: Czech cen. bank battles crown speculators again.

text.p: The Czech National Bank (CNB) battled speculators again on Friday to support the falling crown, but analysts remained pessimistic that the central bank could keep the currency at current levels.
The CNB, for the second consecutive day and fourth time in the past week, intervened on the market after speculators in London pushed the crown sharply lower.

The central bank, which is determined not to devalue what was once the most stable currency in post-communist central Europe, moved when the crown fell to more than five percent below the midpoint of its dollar/mark basket.
The CNB uses the basket to fix the crown's exchange rate daily.

"We saw the intervention today, but I don't know how many other tools the central bank has left," said Breta Tichanek of ING Bank. "The direct buying of crowns is expensive, it can't last for a long time,"
The central bank intervention pulled the crown back to around 2.5 percent below the mid point.
The CNB has fought the wave of speculative short-selling, which has pushed the crown to record lows on several occasions, with a mix of intervention and interest rate tools.
It has raised its Lombard lending facility to 50 percent from 14 percent, its repurchase rate to 75 percent from 12.9 percent, and barred non-residents from Czech money markets.
But dealers said the cost of the CNB's policies, economic
and monetary, was too high to maintain for more than another week or two at most.

"The immediate risk for the crown is a further weakening of the economy," said Tony Norfield, treasury economist at ABN Amro in London. "That would encourage a renewed speculative attack, perhaps forcing the central bank to widen the official currency band."
The central bank is estimated to have spent some $2-3 billion so far in direct intervention alone.
Speculators attacked the currency, believing it to be vulnerable due to a soaring balance of payments deficit and a sharp slowdown in Czech economic growth.
Short sellers can make huge profits if they force the devaluation of a currency, notably when the British pound was forced out of the European exchange rate mechanism in 1992.
